dc:description:
The relationship between LONP1 and Leigh syndrome spectrum was evaluated using the ClinGen Clinical Validity Framework as of December 16, 2020. The LONP1 gene encodes a mitochondrial protease with important roles in proteostasis.

The LONP1 gene has been reported only once in relation to autosomal recessive Leigh syndrome spectrum, in 2018 (PMID: 29518248).  However, defects of this gene are also associated with other mitochondrial phenotypes outside the scope of the Leigh syndrome spectrum gene-disease curation, including CODAS syndrome (cerebral, ocular, dental, auricular, and skeletal anomalies). Evidence supporting the relationship between LONP1 and Leigh syndrome spectrum includes case-level data and experimental data. This curation included two variants identified in one case in one publication (PMID: 29518248). No segregation data were available. Loss of function is implicated as the mechanism of disease. This gene-disease association is also supported by expression and animal models (PMIDs: 18853439, 32521756).

In summary, there is limited evidence to support this gene-disease relationship. While more evidence is needed to establish this relationship definitively, no convincing evidence has emerged that contradicts the gene-disease relationship. This classification was approved by the NICHD U24 ClinGen Mitochondrial Disease Gene Curation Expert Panel on December 16, 2020 (SOP Version 7).

evidence.dc:description:
The homozygous Lonp-/- mouse is embryonic lethal at day 7.5 p.c.

Characterisation of the heterozygous mouse: 
Het mice show no gross phenotypic abnormalities(fig1) MtDNA levels were also similar between WT and het mice
Fig 3. EM analysis of enterocytes showed structurally abnormal mitochondria in the heterozygous mice, mitochondria were swollen, on average longer and  with less organised cristae. 
Fig 4, MEFs: The ultrastructure analysis revealed an increased number of mitochondria in heterozygous MEFs compared with wildtype MEFs.
Using glucose free galactose media, Basal and non-mitochondrial oxygen consumption were significantly lower in het cells, while maximal respiration, despite lower than controls, did not reach statistical significance (Figure 7B and Figure 7 C). 
Figure 7D demonstrates than expression of respiratory complexes was reduced in the heterozygous MEFs, activity of specific complexes was not assessed.
evidence.rdfs:label: KO Mouse model

evidence.dc:description:
https://www.proteinatlas.org/ENSG00000196365-LONP1/brain
LONP1 is ubiquitously expressed, including throughout the brain tissues.
evidence.rdfs:label: Protein Atlas expression

evidence.dc:description:
Both missense variants are located within the conserved ATPase domain of the protein (see molecular modeling, Figure 2)
Function: Using TFAM as a substrate, recombinant LONP1 p.(Tyr565His) showed negligible protease activity compared to WT or the second variant p.Glu733Lys(Fig 5B)
Microscale thermophoresis experiments using fluorescently labelled TFAM showed that p.(Tyr565His) LONP1 prevents binding to the TFAM substrate (Fig 6.). 
Function: when mixed at equimolar amounts, the second variant, p.Glu733Lys has an additive effect on reducing TFAM substrate binding compared to WT +Tyr565His or WT+p.Glu733Lys.

evidence.rdfs:label: Case report: Peter 2018
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
At 24 hours of age the proband presented with respiratory distress, poor feeding and a mixed acidosis with pH 6.85, pCO2 6.7 kPa, bicarbonate 4.0 mmol/l, base deficit 25.9 and plasma lactate peaking at 21 mmol/l (normal range, 0.7–2.1 mmol/l).  He was noted to have an apnea and possible seizure.
There was some developmental progress, smiling at three months of age and developing hand regard. He would babble happily but remained tube fed. 
The proband  died aged 7months during an upper respiratory infection. 
Brain MRI showed a structurally normal brain with mildly increased white matter signal and MRS showed a lactate peak consistent with the hyperlactataemia; median 6.3 mmol/l (range, 1.5–14.0 mmol/l). Text notes that changes are consistent with Leigh syndrome.
Severe depletion of mtDNA in patient muscle (<10% of age-matched controls).
Skeletal Muscle biopsy also showed decrease in markers for complexes I (NDUFB8), III(CORE2) and IV (COXI, II) was apparent, whilst the complex II marker (SDHA) was unaffected (Fig 3). The major mitochondrial transcription and replication factor, TFAM, was also depleted in patient muscle.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Candidate screening of SLC25A4 (NM_001151), MPV17 (NM_002437), SUCLG1 (NM_003849), SUCLA2 (NM_003850), TK2 (NM_004614) and RRM2B (NM_015713) was negative for pathogenic or likely pathogenic variants.
